Conclusion: FNA resulted in a cost savings of €1,641 per patient. P.365 SONOGRAPHY-GUIDED FNA OF SUPERFICIAL LESIONS PERFORMED BY PATHOLOGISTS. THE IMPACT ON PATIENT CARE Y. Daneshbod*, B. Khademi † , S. Negahban*, A. Aledavud* and H. Soleimanpoor* *Cytopathology Department, Dr Daneshbod Laboratory, Shiraz, Iran, Head and Neck Surgery, Shiraz School of Medicine, Shiraz, IranBackground: Since the introduction of sonography-guided FNA (SGFNA) performed by the cytopathologist in the evaluation of head and neck and breast lesions in our daily practice, there has been an improvement in the diagnostic accuracy of FNA with a meaningful reduction of unsatisfactory diagnoses, resulting in a beneficial impact on patient care. Materials and Methods: We reviewed approximately 2078 SGF-NAs of thyroid (n = 854), salivary glands (n = 630), lymph nodes (n = 58), breast (n = 475), and miscellaneous head and neck (n = 61) lesions performed by our group of cytopathologists from January 2008 to March 2009. SGFNA was done using an 18 gauge needle and air dried and alcohol fixed smears were stained with Wright and Papanicolaou methods respectively. Corresponding surgical pathology material was reviewed when available. The sensitivity and specificity was calculated and compared with the palpation-guided FNA done during the year prior to this study. Results: There were 186 positive, 118 suspicious, 36 atypical, 15 unsatisfactory, ten non-diagnostic, and 1685 negative diagnoses. Surgical pathology follow up reports were available in 200 cases.The following are few examples of the impact of SGFNA on patient care. (1) Sialadenosis versus a salivary gland neoplasm (the mass is visible when SGFNA is performed and the procedure is repeated until diagnostic material is obtained). (2) Palpation-guided FNA of a parotid mass originally reported as monomorphic adenoma, was correctly diagnosed as Warthin tumor when SGFNA was performed. (3) A thyroid nodule diagnosed as malignant under palpation-guided FNA in a patient with a known salivary malignancy, was correctly diagnosed as a benign thyroid nodule by SGFNA. Conclusions: (1) Performing SGFNA by the cytopathologist permits the visualization of the mass and may urge the cytopathologist to repeat FNA until adequate sample is obtained reducing unsatisfactory and false negative diagnoses and improving patient care. (2) A higher diagnostic accuracy can be obtained in evaluating cystic lesions by SGFNA sampling of the residual solid-phase component after fluid drainage.(3)It is required the cytopathologist be familiar with the sonographic criteria to select the nodule to be sampled particularly in patients with multinodular goiter or multiple lymph nodes.P.366 CT-GUIDED FNAC OF MEDIASTINAL MASSES M. M. Almeida and P. Campos H. Santa Maria, CHLC, Lisboa, Portugal

FIGREF89.text: CYTOLOGICAL DIAGNOSIS OF CAVITY LYMPHOMA IN A PATIENT HIV NEGATIVE E. Lerma, A. Clua, I. Espinosa, E. Esteva, A. Carreras, N. Dominguez, J. C. Benavente, A. Salazar and J. Prat Hospital de la Santa Creu i Sant Pau, Barcelona, SpainIntroduction: Cavity lymphoma or primary effusion lymphoma is a rare neoplasm of B cells that clinically occurs with massive spills of serous cavities, without tumor masses. It is associated in all cases to the human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8) in HIV+ patients or in immunosuppressed patients. Description of the Case: We report a 77-year-old HIV negative male, who was admitted for breathlessness. A massive thoracic spill was detected on chest x-ray and a thoracocentesis was performed. Results: Cytological study demonstrated abundant isolated large cells with irregular pleomorphic nuclei and prominent nucleoli.The cytoplasm was large and basophilic with occasionally vacuolization. Flow cytometry showed a small population of polyclonal B lymphoid cells with abundant CD4 positive T Lymphoid cells. The immunohistochemical study performed in the cell block revealed focal positivity in large cells to CD138 and CD45. The HHV-8 was strongly positive in all tumor cells. Rearrangement of variable region (FR3) of the immunoglobulin heavy chain was monoclonal. Conclusion: The combination of smears, cell-block, immunohistochemistry, flow cytometry and cell rearrangement allows the diagnosis of primary effusion lymphoma. P.370 FINE NEEDLE ASPIRATION OF THYROID IN LIQUID BASED SMEARS P. Agapito, V. Sousa, M. Ruivo, I. Ferreira and H. Garcia CEDAP -Pathology Diagnostic Center, Coimbra, PortugalObjective: In our Laboratory we usually receive samples of fine needle aspiration of thyroid: either in direct smears or liquid based preparation (Thin Prep Ò ). We want to demonstrate our experience in Liquid based preparation in thyroid, for the last 6 years. Materials and Methods: Total of thyroid samples -3846; Liquid based preparation of thyroid smears -1317. Results: The diagnosis were: (1) 1256 Colloid Nodules, 634 of those were Cystic Colloid Nodules, (2) 32 Follicular Tumors, three with histological correlation, (3) nine Pappillary Carcinomas, one with histological correlation, (4) 15 Lymphocytic Thyroiditis, (5) five Hashimoto's Thyroiditis. Conclusion: It is possible with accurate diagnosis and experience has reliable results as we are demonstrate in this study.

TABREF8.text: P.172 PROSPECTIVE COMPARISON OF THINPREP â AND PREPSTAIN â LBC IN CERVICAL CYTOLOGY: A PILOT STUDY F. Willocx, T. Crabbe´and C. Bourgain Department for Pathology, Universitair Ziekenhuis Brussel, Laarbeeklaan, Brussels, BelgiumObjective: Liquid-based cytology has become the standard for cervical cancer screening. Actually, two FDA-approved methods are available, ThinPrep Ò and PrepStain Ò . Vast evidence comparing LBC to conventional cytology has demonstrated a superiority for specimen adequacy and detection of low-grade epithelial lesions. However, there are no prospective studies comparing different liquid-based techniques. The purpose of this study was therefore to compare the performance of both techniques. Materials and Methods: In 2008, 8050 cervical samples were collected and assessed prospectively at the department of Cytopatology, UZBrussel. Referring clinicians were allocated randomly to either ThinPrep Ò or PrepStain Ò sampling devices. All specimens were screened within the same cytotechnologist-pathologist team and reported according to the Bethesda 2001 system. On all samples with a cervical epithelial lesion, reflex high risk HPV testing was performed with the Hybrid Capture Ò test. For all women, cytological and histological follow-up data of epithelial lesions were recorded. Results: 3919 Thinprep Ò and 4131 PrepStain Ò samples were included. The mean age of the women was 43.3 and 41.6 years respectively, with no difference within the groups; 92.2% of all samples collected between the age of 25 and 65. ThinPrep Ò compared to PrepStain Ò revealed identical specimen adequacy (98.3% and 99.6%). Epithelial lesions were 4.01% and 4.65%: 43/40 ASC-US, 6/7 ASC-H, 81/115 LSIL, 23/25 HSIL, O/1 squamous carcinoma, 2/2 AGC and 2/2 adenocarcinoma. No differences were observed between both techniques for the number of detected lesions or diagnostic cytological criteria. HR-HPV was found in 3.19% and 3.49% respectively (ASC-US 58.1% versus 37.50%, ASC-H 83.3% versus 57.1%, LSIL 87.8% versus 88.6%, HSIL 100%).Conclusion: This pilot study demonstrates an equivalent performance for Thinprep Ò and PrepStain Ò processed cervical LBC specimens for specimen quality and epithelial lesion detection. A non-significant trend for a higher correlation between the ASC-lesions and the presence of high-risk HPV in the Thinprep Ò group needs to be further evaluated.S. Iannaccio, R. Heyn, A. Lukic, S. Villani, E. Battaglione and M. R. Giovagnoli II Faculty of Medicine, Sapienza University of Rome, Italy

TABREF9.text: P.177 KNOWLEDGE & ATTITUDE ANALYSIS ABOUT UTERINE CANCER PREVENTION N. Rocha, M. F. Guimara˜es, M. Silva, C. Padilha, V. Carvalho, S. Souza, L. Padilha and V. Balboa Rad Qualy Center, Rio de Janeiro, BrazilIntroduction: In Brazil cervix cancer causes 15% of women's death. The higher taxes are in class economical least favored. Pap test isn't done periodically for lack of knowledge, fear, shame or ignorance. Despite its cheapness, not invasive, available in health centers in Brazil the structure for the diagnosis is still insufficient to reduce our high rates of mortality.Objectives: Identify knowledges and attitudes on the prevention of uterine cancer. Analyze factors associated to low adhesion. Propose actions to increase awareness about necessity of this test. Methods: Questionnaire handed to 65 women of the Rio de Janeiro during a social action. Participants were informed about importance of the study, answered it for free and spontaneously. Parameters considered: Appropriate knowledge: know or have already heard about Pap test. Unsuitable knowledge: Not know about Pap Test Appropriate attitude: Have done Pap Test in the last three years and know about its necessity Unsuitable attitude: find not much necessary, unnecessary, no opinion about it, did it last above three years or never. Results: 10.77% never did Pap test. 3% had it suspicious or positive and 6% could not inform. 25% heard about HPV, 22% heard but didn't know its relationship with cancer. 11% had never done Pap test. 42% had cancer in the family. 5% could not answer. Average age 33 years, from 14 to 61, (two didn't answer this item). 78.5% hadn't sufficient information on the importance of Pap Test and would like more. Conclusion: Necessity of most effective social education. Least favored populations need special attention with preventive directed actions. Assimilation of the Pap Test passes firstly for awareness of health's managers themselves with more compromising in the preventive health's actions. Primary and secondary prevention reduce efficiently the cervical cancer. Relevance: knowledge and attitude contribute significantly to the adhesion on the Pap Test.P.178 CORRELATION BETWEEN HPV INFECTION AND COLPOCYTOHISTOLOGICAL CHANGES IN THE LOWER FEMALE GENITAL TRACT Z. TABREF31.text: P.232 ASCITIC FLUID CYTOLOGY OF MALIGNANT MIXED MÜ LLERIAN TUMOR OF THE PERITONEUM: REPORT OF 2 CASES WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO P53 STATUS N. Kato*, I. Asanuma † and T. Motoyama* *Department of Pathology, Yamagata University School of Medicine, Yamagata, Japan, Laboratory Division, Yamagata Prefectural Kahoku Hospital, Kahoku, JapanObjective: Malignant mixed mü llerian tumors (MMMTs) rarely originate in the female peritoneum. Peritoneal MMMT, as well as its uterine or ovarian counterpart, is characterized by biphasic histologic components, including carcinoma of the mü llerian type and sarcoma. In ascitic fluid cytology of MMMT, however, the biphasic pattern is less evident than in tissue sections, and heterogeneity of cell differentiation makes the cytologic diagnosis difficult, especially in distinguishing tumor cells from reactive mesothelial cells. The purpose of this study is to identify the tumor cells by referring to p53 status. Materials and Methods: Ascitic fluid smears for two peritoneal MMMT cases were analyzed by Pap staining and p53 immunostaining. p53 alteration was examined by single strand conformation polymorphism and sequencing analyses. Results: In both cases, tumor cells in ascitic fluid smears, as well as carcinomatous cells and sarcomatous cells in tissue sections, showed distinct nuclear immunostaining for p53, whereas mesothelial cells did not. Subsequent genetic analyses revealed that both cases had one base insertion at codon 141. Conclusion: Immunocytochemistry for p53 is helpful in identifying tumor cells of MMMT in ascitic fluid smears. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report showing p53 overexpression and its genetic background in MMMT of the peritoneum.P.233 DETECTION OF SYT AND EWS GENE REARRANGEMENTS BY DUAL-COLOR BREAK-APART CISH ON LIQUID-BASED CYTOLOGY SAMPLES OF SYNOVIAL SARCOMA AND EWING SARCOMA T. Motoi*, A. Kumagai*, K. Hayashi † , T. Imamura † , A. Yoshida ‡ and T. Fukusato* *Department of Pathology, Teikyo University School of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Surgical Pathology, Teikyo University Hospital, Tokyo, Japan, à Department of Pathology, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, JapanObjective: Synovial sarcoma (SS) and Ewing sarcoma (ES) are high grade sarcomas which constantly harbor specific chromosomal translocation. Chromosome 18 and 22 are involved to result in SYT and EWS rearrangements respectively. We have developed a novel method for the cytological detection of such rearranged genes using dual-color break-apart chromogenic in situ hybridization (dc-CISH) on liquid-based cytology (LBC) samples. Materials and Methods: LBC samples were prepared from resected or biopsied specimens of 5 SS and 5 ES using BD Surepath (Becton Dickinson). The dc-CISH probes for SYT and EWS were customly designed to span known breakpoints and the signals were visualized by DAKO DUO CISH (DAKO). The numbers of paired and unpaired signals were counted in sixty nuclei per sample. The CISH results were correlated with SYT-SSX and EWS-Fli1 chimeric gene status by RT-PCR. Results: Split signals indicating rearranged SYT were detected in all 5 SSs, but not in ESs. In contrast, split EWS signals were detected in all 5 ESs but not in SSs. The presence of rearrangement was verified by detecting SYT-SSX in all SS samples and EWS-Fli1 in all ES samples by RT-PCR respectively. Conclusion: dc-CISH was successfully applied to detect gene rearrangement on LBC specimens of SS and ES. CISH enables simultaneous visualization of genomic abnormality and the morphology of tumor cells. Thin-layered preparation with clean background of LBC facilitates accurate interpretation. CISH and LBC, therefore, may serve as a prime combination for the cytological diagnosis of translocation-associated sarcomas such as SS and ES.Bronchioalveolar lavage (BAL) is commonly used in the diagnosis of lung disorders. It is the preferred technique for sampling alveolar lung tissue in immunocompromised patients with diffuse or localised infiltrative lung disease and other lung disorders such as pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. A 54 year old female, an ex smoker with a 37 pack year smoking history, presented with progressive shortness of breath of 6 months duration. Chest x-rays revealed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. CT scan of the chest showed patchy ground glass opacities. A bronchoscopy and bronchioalveolar lavage were performed. The lavage fluid was opaque and milky. Cell block sections of the fluid showed granular eosinophilic material which stained positively with PAS diastase. Electron microscopy demonstrated numerous osmiophilic structures with a lamellar pattern, consistent with surfactant protein supporting the light microsopic diagnosis of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). PAP is a rare disorder (one of the orphan lung diseases) in which lipoproteinaceous material (surfactant protein) accumulates in the alveoli. Recently, granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF) has been proven to be involved in the pathogenesis of the condition, with possible therapeutic implications. There are three clinically distinct forms of the disease; congenital (2%), secondary (< 10%), and acquired (90%). The gold standard for the diagnosis of PAP has long been considered to be an open/thoracoscopic lung biopsy. By appropriate use of BAL fluid, and, in particular, recognition of the macroscopic appearance of the lavage fluid, a diagnosis of PAP can be established using cell block preparations and electron microscopy, thus avoiding the need for surgery and associated morbidity and financial burden.References: 1. Maygarden S, Iacocca MV, Funkhouser, WK, Novotny DB. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Diag Cytopathol 2001; 24: 389-395. 2. Trapnell, BC, Whitsett, JA, Nakata, K. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. N Engl J Med 2003; 349: 2527-2539. 3. Ioachimescu, OC, Kavuru MS. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Chronic Respir Dis 2006; 3: 149-159. P.235 CYTOLOGICAL STUDY OF 28 CASES WITH SOLID-PAPILLARY CARCINOMA OF THE BREAST M. Yamada*, Y. Otsuki † , S.-i. Shimizu † , F. Tanioka ‡ , H. Ogawa § and H. Kobayashi † *Department of Clinical Laboratory, Seirei Hamamatsu General Hospital, Hamamatsu, Japan, Department of Pathology, Seirei Hamamatsu General Hospital, Hamamatsu, Japan, à Department of Pathology, Iwata City Hospital, Iwata, Japan, § Department of Pathology, Seirei Mikatahara General Hospital, Hamamatsu, Japan Objective: Solid-papillary carcinoma (SPC) of the breast is a very rare tumor with low-grade malignant potential and neuroendocrine differentiation. Only a few articles have been published on the cytology of SPC and the maximum number of cases in the articles was less than 9. We report the cytological characteristics of 28 cases of the SPC. Materials and Methods: All the patients were Japanese women; aged 31-80 (mean age 63.5 year). Most of the specimens were taken from the palpable masses by fine needle aspiration. We made cytological, histological, and immunohistochemical examinations of all the cases. Results: Cytologically, 18 cases showed high cellularity, highly discohesive clusters with numerous isolated cells, and severe overcrowding of tumor cells. The tumor cells showed small round to oval and bland nuclei with finely granular chromatin in 26 cases and they showed inconspicuous nucleoli in 27 cases. A low nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio and eccentric nuclei were seen in 25 cases. We have detected neither abnormal naked nuclei of tumor cell origin nor oval naked nuclei of myoepithelial cell origin. Histologically, all the tumors showed solid and expansive growth of epithelial tumor cells in the duct lobular units accompanied by delicate fibrovascular septa. Rosette and nuclear palisading at the stromal interphase were always seen. Twenty cases contained invasive components. The tumor cells were positive for Grimelius staining and/or chromogranin A in all the cases. Conclusion: We concluded that the coexistence of malignant and benign features was the most characteristic of the cytology of SPC. variations of nuclei size for medullary carcinoma in comparison with some other thyroid tumors (oncocytic tumors and tall cell variant of papillary carcinoma). Conclusion: The results of morphometry show that image analysis provides more objective diagnosis of thyroid medullary carcinoma. J. Luz*, R. Roque † and P. Mendonça* *Instituto Polite´cnico de Lisboa, Escola Superior de Tecnologia da Sau´de de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal, Instituto Português de Oncologia de Lisboa Francisco Gentil, EPE, Lisboa, PortugalObjective: The aim of this study was to investigate which is the best laboratorial method to process urinary cytology. It compares the centrifugation Cytospin processing method, a very well known technique with valuable results, with a newer liquid based cytology technique, Liqui-PREP processing method.Materials and Methods:The study consisted of 43 voided urine specimens, which were all processed by both methods; Cytospin and Liqui-PREP. The resulting slides were evaluated through the Optical Microscope by three independent observers according to the following parameters: Cellularity; Squamous Cells; Urothelial Cells; Inflammatory Cells; Cellular Overlapping; Cellular Preservation; Artifacts and Background. The data collected was processed using Microsoft Office Excel 2007 and the statistical software SPSS 16.0 mainly through the calculation of totals, averages, standard deviation and the Student t-test for independent samples. Results: The global averages of both methods were analyzed and the Cytospin processing method achieved higher values. The results of the Student t-test show a p value higher than the a value, which means that there are differences in both methods. Conclusion: The final results somehow diverged from the bibliography consulted. These differences may be due to the biological nature of the products used in the other studies or a consistent implementation of the techniques in the respective labs. The Cytospin method, when compared to that of Liqui-PREP achieves a better final score, thus we may conclude that it presents better results in the evaluation of urinary Cytology slides, of voided urine samples, processed in our Cytopathology laboratory.M. Garcia-Bonafe, C. Dolz, A. Vilella, M. Company, M. Ramis and J. Moyano Son Llatzer Hospital, Palma de Mallorca, SpainAims: To evaluate the utility of cytologic study of bile and pancreatic duct brushings obtained with endoscopic retrograde cholangiography and compare the precision and diagnostic value of specimen processing by a conventional method and the ThinPrep Ò method.Materials and Methods:We reviewed 152 consecutive duct brushings (143 bile duct, 7 pancreatic duct, and 2 indeterminate). Sixty-four were prepared by the ThinPrep Ò (TP) system and the remaining were conventional preparations (CP). Brushings were reported as insufficient, benign, and malignant or suspected malignancy. The definite diagnoses were established by biopsy (34 cases), or tumor markers (CEA and CA 19.9), diagnostic imaging (CT or MRI), and clinical follow-up.Results: Among the 88 CP examined, nine were insufficient (10%), 46 were benign (38%) and 33 (51%) were suspect or malignant. There were 27 adenocarcinomas, four cholangiocarcinomas, one lymphoma and one oat cell metastasis. The definite diagnosis revealed eight false-negatives and no false-positives; six of the insufficient samples corresponded to carcinomas. The sensitivity of CP study was 80%, specificity 100%, positive predictive value 100% and negative predictive value 82%. Among the 64 TP examined, 33 were benign and 29 malignant, with no cases of suspected malignancy, and no insufficient samples. There were 23 adenocarcinomas, five cholangiocarcinomas, and one metastatic endometrial carcinoma. No false-positives or false-negatives were found. The sensitivity, specificity and predictive values for TP cytology were all 100%.Conclusions: ThinPrep Ò showed better performance than CP for duct brushing diagnosis. The following factors may have contributed to these results: (i) greater cellularity in samples processed by TP (no insufficient samples), (ii) better preservation or fixation, thereby enhancing details, particularly nuclear features, and improving malignant diagnosis, in addition to reducing cases of suspected non-specific diagnosis, and (ii) presence of necrosis more easily observed in samples processed by TP.C. Kaneko*, T. K. Kobayashi † , K. Hasegawa* and Y. Udagawa* *FUjita Health University, Toyoake, Japan, Saiseikai Shigaken Hospital, Toyoake, Japan

TABREF32.text: Results and Discussion: We evaluated the cell block method using a glucomannan. Electron micrograph of the specimen showing well preserved morphology. The cell-block method has a high utility value and is sufficiently applicable not only to special staining and immunostaining, but also to genetic testing and TEM examination. Thus this new technique approach should find wide application in the future.A. Kumagai*, T. Motoi*, Y. Ota † , Y. Oishi † , A. Yoshida ‡ , S. Fukumoto ‡ , Y. Takeuchi † , K.-I. Ohashi † and T. Fukusato* *Teikyo University, Tokyo, Japan, Toranomon Hospital, Tokyo, Japan, à University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan Introduction: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor (PMT) is a rare mesenchymal neoplasm associated with oncogenic osteomalacia (OO). Recently, fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) secreted by PMT was identified as a cause of OO. We here report cytological features of PMT with FGF23 analysis by immunocytochemistry and chromogenic in situ hybridization (CISH). Case: A 34-year old man with longstanding osteomalacia, noticed a subcutaneous tumor in the abdomen 4 years ago. OO was suspected, and the tumor was excised. Cytological findings: Imprint and thin-layer preparations made from the resected tumor showed individually dispersed or small aggregates of bland spindle cells in a background of finely granular calcified matrix. The nuclei of tumor cells were round to oval with small conspicuous nucleoli. Osteoclast-like giant cells and macrophages were admixed. These findings were consistent with PMT, mixed connective tissue variant (PMTMCT), which was confirmed by histological examination. FGF23 analysis: Immunocytochemically, tumor cells were focally positive for FGF23. Karyotype analysis revealed diploid and tetraploid tumor cells. No FGF23 gene amplification was identified by dual-color CISH. Conclusion: Cytological examination might be applied to systemic survey of tumor responsible for OO. In such case, the above features serve a key to the cytological diagnosis of PMTMCT. Cytological preparation is also suitable for immunodetection of FGF23, thus strongly supporting the diagnosis. Although underlying mechanism of FGF23 overexpression remains unclear, possibility of genomic amplification of FGF23 was excluded by the present CISH analysis.Tetraploid tumor cells may reflect mitotic failure and chromosomal instability of PMTMCT. COMPARISING THE STAINING QUALITY BETWEEN PAPANICOLAOU AND MODIFIED PAPANICOLAOU TECHNIQUES IN ARCHIVE SLIDES P. Mendonc¸a and C. Ladeira Instituto Polite´cnico de Lisboa, Escola Superior de Tecnologia da Sau´de de Lisboa, Portugal The Papanicolaou (Pap) stain is the most popular technique to stain epithelial cells for exfoliate cytology. The Modified Pap technique (Ayyad et al., 2006) consists of some variations of the conventional Pap stain, which nuclear stain is with Mayer's hematoxylin for 4 minutes, followed by a rinse in a stream of gently running water for 15 minutes and other variations. The aim of this study was to compare the staining quality between Pap and Modified Pap techniques in 2 year old archive slides.One hundred cytologic smears were taken from buccal mucosa of 50 individuals. For each individual, two slides were prepared by smearing the oral scrapings on the slides for a total of 100 slides (50 slides stained with Pap stain and 50 with Modified Pap stain). The slides were evaluated under a light microscope with 1000-fold magnification using oil immersion according to parameters of celular preservation, acidofilic and basofilic strutures, nuclear membrane, cytoplasmatic diferenciation, staining intensity, staining artifacts and the possibility or not of obtaining a diagnostic. The evaluation of these two techniques in 2007 had similar results, for instance, the Pap stain had a score of 23 and the Modified Pap had a score of 21. The evaluation after 2 years is very different; the Pap stain had score of 19 and Modified Pap a score of 8. Pap staining maintains can keep the quality of the slide over time where as in Modified Pap staining the colour disappears and makes the diagnosis impossible. P.244 EVALUATION OF STAINING TECHNIQUES ON THE RESULTS OF MICRONUCLEUS IN EXFOLIATED ORAL MUCOSA CELLS C. Ladeira and P. Mendonc¸a Instituto Polite´cnico de Lisboa, Escola Superior de Tecnologia da Sau´de de Lisboa, Portugal Micronuclei in exfoliated epithelial cells are widely used as biomarkers of cancer risk in humans. The aim of this study consists in the comparison of seven techniques for staining for buccal mucosal cells to detect micronuclei (MN). These tecniques are: Papanicolaou (PAP), Modified Papanicolaou, May-Grü nwald Giemsa (MGG), Giemsa, Harris's Hematoxylin, Feulgen with Fast Green counterstain and Feulgen without counterstain. Seventy cytologic smears (two per individual) were taken from the buccal mucosa by scraping with endobrush. Ten smears were stained with each tecnique. The slides were evaluated under a light microscope with 1000-fold magnification using oil immersion according with the parameters of nuclear, micronuclear, citoplasmatic staining intensity and staining artefacts. The results with Feulgen with Light Green as counterstain and Harris's Hematoxylin weren't satisfactory. All the other results were classified as satisfactory, with scores of 14 to PAP stain and 12 to MGG and Giemsa. The higher and maximum score (20) was obtained with Feulgen without counterstain. Feulgen without counterstain was the preferred method for detecting MN in buccal mucosa cells because of its especificity to DNA. A. Martins*, C. Gonc¸alves*, J. Pestana*, T. Carpinteiro*, R. Roque* , † and P. Mendonça* *Instituto Polite´cnico de Lisboa, Escola Superior de Tecnologia da Sau´de de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal, Instituto Português de Oncologia de Lisboa Francisco Gentil, EPE, Lisboa, Portugal Objectives: Compare three Techniques of cell block (CB) methods, Agar-Agar (AA), Thrombin (T) and Shandon Cytoblock Ò Cell Block Preparation System (SC), and identify which one leads to better technical results, better quality and more reliable diagnosis in bronchial secretions samples. Materials and Methods: It was studied 40 samples of bronchial secretions from ThinPrep specimens for each of the three techniques,resulting in the end a total of 120 CB's. Sections prepared from the CB¢s were evaluated for cellularity, nuclear and cytoplasm preservation, staining and artifacts, by three observers. To each one of these parameters a score was allocated. Each parameter was graded on an ordinal scale from zero to two and a weighting factor was also assigned in order to differentiate its importance in the study.The final quality evaluation of the slides was calculated according to the formula bellow: [2 · (Cellularity) +2 · (NP) + 2 · (CP) + 2 · (Staining) + Artifacts].The data were analyzed through the parametric test OneWay ANOVA and were treated with resource to Microsoft Excel software of the Office 2003 and to the SPSS version 15.0. Results: The average of the technical final score was for the T 14.94; AA 12.24 and SC 11.68. PT technique presents better results in all parameters under study, except the parameter artifacts.The results from the descriptive statistics indicate the T technique as the one with less dispersion followed by the AA and SC techniques. Conclusion: The particularity of this technique is to increase the diagnosis quality, through the use of material, with morphological pattern similar to that obtained by histology. The results indicate that T is a technique that allows CB's with better quality, with good representation and cellular preservation for Bronchial Secretions samples. A. Martins*, C. Gonc¸alves*, J. Pestana*, T. Carpinteiro*, R. Roque* , † and P. Mendonça* *Instituto Polite´cnico de Lisboa, Escola Superior de Tecnologia da Sau´de de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal, Instituto Português de Oncologia de Lisboa Francisco Gentil, EPE, Lisboa, Portugal Objectives: Process samples of Bronchial Secretions in Cell Block (CB) by the Agar Agar methodology and evaluate their final qual-ity. Identify the technical aspects for the achievement of better results and better technical quality of CB's. Materials and Methods: The group of study is constituted by 40 samples of bronchial secretions from ThinPrep Specimens. TheAgar Agar methodology was performed on these samples, resulting in the end a total of 40 CB's. The CBs quality evaluation was made using the microscopic observation of the slides and the allocation of scores to the following parameters: Cellularity, Nuclear and Cytoplasm Preservation (NP, CP), Staining and Artifacts. Each parameter was graded on an ordinal scale from zero to two and a weighting factor was also assigned in order to differentiate its importance in the study. In the end each slide obtained a score calculated by:[2 ·  and [12-18], to whom was given a nominal classification, which translates into: inadequate, acceptable and good, respectively. Results: For the slides obtained, three had inadequate, 13 had acceptable and the remaining 24, good, so for the most strip, the score is closer to the maximum interval. The average of the technical final score was 12.24.Conclusion: This study showed that this method, besides having the advantage of low cost and rapid execution, does not cause the shrinkage or disintegration of the sediment during dehydration and embedding in paraffin.In addition it also helped to optimize technical aspects in the AA protocol like the importance of measuring the gel concentration and its preparation to avoid loss of material.P.247 EXPERIENCE WITH AN ONLINE DIAGNOSTIC TEST CREATED FOR THE EFCS TUTORIALS U. Schenck and T. Sauer Institute of Pathology, Technical University of Munich, Munich, Germany; Department of Pathology, Oslo University Hospital, Ulleval, Oslo, Norway Objective: Starting in 2008 the European Federation of Cytology Societies (EFCS) organises cytologi-cal tutorials. It was agreed to create an accompanying online test for the tutorial participants. Materials and Methods: An Online test with 30 single choice questions on cytological images from all parts of cytology was established on an online education system www.zytologie.de / http://zytotraining.schenck.de without additional programming. The questions were entered as individ-ual questions with images, compiled to a test and integrated into a special course allowing for individual measurement of performance. The results were evaluated with the test reporting module of the platform. Results: 56 persons were registered. Time consumption was 34 hours. 47 took the test. three answered only 1, 24 and 29 questions resp. Among 1374 questions answered, 59.2% answers were correct. Individual test results ranged from 20% to 100%. Correct answers for the individual questions were between 28% (a difficult benign breast FNA and 87% (a papillary thyroid carcinoma with nuclear inclu-sions). The online test ran smoothly without technical problems. Conclusions: Online testing can be handled easily today. Discussion and options for future events: Integration of online tests into a framework of continuous online training and communication, separa-tion of tests for gynaecological and extragenital cytology, inclusion of theoretical questions, removal of too difficult questions, checking the distribution and number of cases from different organs, integra-tion of additional learning material after each question, systematic collection of feedback. Cytologists, MD and CT are invited to register with www.zytologie.de free of charge. A. Emmanouilidou*, E. Tsiambas † and M. Kapetanaki † *Department of Clinical Cytology, Sismanoglio General Hospital, Athens, Greece, Department of Clinical cytology, Army Veterans Hospital 'NIMTS', Athens, Greece

TABREF33.text: P.249 THE EFFICACY OF CYTOLOGY FOLLOW UP IN LUNG CANCER AFTER SURGERY AND CHEMOTHERAPY A. Emmanouilidou*, D. Melemeni † , A. Blana*, E. Ellina*, 3N. Maounis*, V. Polychronopoulos ‡ and S. Michailidis † *Department of Clinical Cytology, Sismanoglio General Hospital, Athens, Greece, 1st Department of Respiratory Medicine, Sismanoglio General Hospital, Athens, Greece, à 3rd Department of Respiratory Medicine, Sismanoglio General Hospital, Athens, GreeceObjectives: We evaluated 50 patients by cytology follow up (sputum, brushing, washing) who urderwent surgery (lobectomy or total pneumonectomy) caused by lung cancer and under chemotherapy treatment. We estimated the status of the disease, possible recurrences and the response or not to the chemotherapy cycles according to the protocols. Materials and Methods: We studied 300 cytologic samples (sputum, brushings, bronchial washings) obtained from 50 patients after surgery and chemotherapy cycles. All cytologic specimens were stained by the Papanicolaou technique. Results: From the 50 studied patients only 30 responded to the chemotherapy. We reported the characteristic cytomorphologic changes due to the response to the chemotherapeutic drugs. Presence of malignant cells in cytologic specimens indicates no response to the administrated chemotherapy and perhaps MDR reaction.Conclusion: Cytologic follow up is an important adjuvant examination in patients with lung cancer after surgery and chemotherapy. TABREF35.text: ON FNAC MATERIAL FROM BREAST CARCINOMAS E. Beraki and T. Sauer Department of Pathology, Oslo University Hospital, Ulleval, Oslo, NorwayObjective: Dako DuoCISHTM is intended for dual-color chromogenic visualization of signals achieved with two FISH labelled probes (Texas Red and FITC). The kit is optimized for FFPE tissue sections form the breast carcinomas. Our earlier experience is that, such procedures do not work well on cytological materials with out major modifications. The purpose of this study is therefore to develop a method for double-CISH-HER-2 gene/chromosome on breast carcinomas from FNAC. Materials and Methods: The procedure was tested on FNAC materials from breast carcinoma cases as well as some benign lesions. This included direct smears and rest material from liquid suspensions. Both cytospins and Cytyc ThinPrep preparations were made. This technique includes the manually hybridization procedures and an automated chromogenic-staining on the Dako Autostainer. Results: Our procedure generates clear distinct red (HER-2) and blue (CEN-17) signals on the same slide-identified by bright field microscopy 40X objectives. Conclusion: This procedure is optimised for cytological material and can be used as a routine procedure when it is not feasible to obtain histological materiale from a breast carcinoma or from metastatic lesions.N. Bongiovanni Department of Pathology, Geneva University Hospital, Geneva, SwitzerlandObjective: The small cell variant of medullary thyroid carcinoma (SCV-MTC) is a very unusual tumor, often misdiagnosed, with poorer prognosis than conventional MTC. This tumor type closely resembles oat-cell pulmonary carcinoma or lymphoma. Congo-red staining and immunoreactivity for calcitonin (CT) could be absent in this variant. We describe the clinical and cytopathological features of a challenging case of SCV-MTC on thyroid fine-needle aspiration (FNA). Materials and Methods: A 43-year-old woman had a palpable mass on the right side of her neck. Serum CT level was just above normal range. FNA and total thyroidectomy were performed.

The aim of this study is to verify the use of LBC-FNC as compared with Cell Block (CB) technique, according to cellular and architectural features, in liver FNC. Materials and Methods: Over a period of 18 months (2007-2008) we observed 114 patients who underwent hepatic Fine Needle Aspiration under US guidance using a 21 G CIBA needle. In 92 (43 females and 49 males; mean age 57.2 years, range 23-87) out of 114 cases malignant cells were revealed. Tallada Pathology Department, Vall d'Hebron University Hospital, Barcelona, Spain *Radiology Departament, Vall d'Hebron University Hospital, Barcelona, Spain Background: FNAC is non-invasive, useful method and proved cost-effective technique for neoplastic lesions diagnosis. Study was designed to evaluate our experience useing FNAC, its utility and reliability in the diagnosis of bone metastatic carcinoma (MC). Design: We reviewed 1017 CT-guided FNAC of bone lesions performed between 1990-2007. We selected 347 MC. Aspirated material was stained with Diff-Quik and Papanicolaou. Tissue cell block (CB) was available in 330 cases.Immunohistochemistry (IHC) performed in 177 samples.

Materials and Methods: Cervical smears of 320 cases with ASCUS or SIL diagnosis were analyzed using the HPV Clinical Arrays genotyping (Genomica) after PCR DNA amplification. ASCUS diagnosis was based on hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and megacaryosis alone or in combination. SIL diagnosis was made only when koilocytosis and or dysplastic cells where present. Results: HPV was detected in 97/185 (52.43%) ASCUS, 118/133 (88.72%) LSIL and 2/2 (100%) HSIL (CIN2) cases. High risk HPV was found in 79/97 (81.44%) ASCUS and in 106/120 (88.33%) SIL cases. Multiple hrHPV types were present in 30/97 (30.92%) ASCUS and in 57/120 (47.5%) SIL cases. The same HPV types prevailed with similar percentages in both groups: in ASCUS high risk HPV51 and HPV 53 (31.95%), HPV16 and HPV 18(13.40%), and low risk HPV6 (16.49%), and in SIL high risk HPV53 (28.33%), HPV16, (21.66%), HPV51 (20.83%), HPV31 (15.83%), HPV66

A 49-year-old woman presented for hirsutism, deep voice and hypertension. Ultrasonography (US) revealed a solitary tumor mass, 8 cm in size, of the right adrenal gland. Laboratory tests showed it to be a hormonally active, androgen secreting tumor (elevated testosterone level), which was consistent with the clinical picture of the disease. Histopathologic analysis pointed to adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC), a low risk carcinoma according to Weiss' classification. On regular follow up US study performed at 1 year, a 65 · 43 mm growth was diagnosed in the lower pole of the right kidney. The finding was verified by computerized tomography and the patient was reoperated on. Exploration revealed secondary growth in the region of greater omentum, without infiltration of adjacent organs. Histopathologic analysis indicated metastatic ACC. At 8 months of the second operation and after six chemotherapy cycles according to EAP protocol, enlarged para-aortic lymph nodes and a node along the upper pole of the right kidney were diagnosed by cytologic puncture. Cytologic analysis showed numerous large tumor cells (individual and in papillary clusters) with polymorphic, hyperchromic, irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli with perinucleolar halo, and abundant pale basophilic cytoplasm. The cells were positive for vimentin, NSE, synaptophysin and epithelial markers (BerEP4 and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA)). Conclusion: ACC is a rare tumor of high malignant potential, deriving from adrenal gland cortex. Morphologically (histopathology and cytology), there is the problem of differential diagnosis from adenoma on the one hand, and from renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) on the other hand. Proliferation markers such as Ki67 or DNA-ploidy help differentiate ACC from adenoma, and cellular markers (alpha-fetoprotein, CD10, RCC marker, vimentin, EMA, keratins 7 and 20, alpha-inhibin, and polyclonal antibodies against carcinoembryonic antigen (pCEA)) from RCC and HCC. Objective: The aim of the study was: (1) to assess the appropriateness and adequacy of lymph node puncture for flow cytometry analysis in case of benign and primary malignant lymph node lesions, and (2) to assess the value of cytologic analysis in various groups of malignant and benign lymph node lesions by determination of B lymphocyte clonality using the method of flow cytometry. Materials and Methods: The study included samples of 239 patients submitted to cytologic analysis and flow cytometry analysis of cellular markers. Statistica 7.1 software was employed on statistical analysis. Results: Study results showed cytologic puncture to be an appropriate method to obtain an adequate cell count for flow cytometry analysis irrespective of the benign or malignant nature of lymphoproliferative disease. Analysis of the percentage of lymphatic cells according to their size (cells of normal and small lymphocyte characteristics, SLY; cells of large lymphatic cell characteristics, LLY; and cells of other mononuclear cell characteristics, OMS) showed benign lymphoproliferative diseases to be characterized by SLY, B-non-Hodgkin's lymphomas mostly by LLY, and lymphomas of non-B-cell origin mostly by OMS. B-lymphocyte clonality is generally a characteristic of B-malignant lymphoproliferative diseases (B-NHL). In some cases of B-NHL, clonality cannot be demonstrated if the percentage of clonal lymphatic cells is low (in some cases of diffuse B large cell lymphoma abundant in T-lymphocytes), or if large lymphatic cells have been destroyed by manipulation (puncture, mononuclear separation, etc.). Conclusion: Cytodiagnosis is a simple and reliable method to differentiate benign from primary lymphoproliferative diseases (lymphomas) and secondary malignancies (metastases), as well as in typing and subtyping of malignant lymphomas. As cytologic puncture provides an adequate cell count for flow cytometry in lymphoproliferative disease, diagnostic accuracy and reliability are upgraded by combined use of these two methods. Background: Soft tissue myoepithelioma is an extremely rare neoplasm arising in the subcutaneous or deep subfascial soft tissues of the extremities. To our knowledge, the cytologic features of soft tissue myoepithelioma have been not described in the English literature. We report the imprint cytologic features of a case of soft tissue myoepithelioma. Case: A 18-year-old man presented with a solitary mass on the radial aspect of the right forearm for 5 months. MR images showed a well defined mass in the forearm. The mass was excised. The tumor measured 3.0 · 1.8 · 1.5 cm. The cut surface was well demarcated, lobulating, yellowish myxoid, and soft. The touch imprint cytologic smears from the mass were obtained. The alcohol-fixed smears were stained with hematoxylin-eosin and Papanicolaou stain. Microscopic examination showed round to ovalshaped tumor cells in single cells, sheets or clusters. These cells had relatively uniform, round to ovoid nuclei, with finely granular chromatin. The nuclei were centrally or eccentrically located. The cells had eosinophilic or indistinct cytoplasm. No significant nuclear atypia was observed. The background was myxoid. No necrosis was found. On immunohistochemical stain, the tumor cells were positive for cytokeratin (AE1/AE3) and S-100 protein. On the histologic examination, the tumor was multilobulated and myxoid. The tumor cells were round and epithelioid. There was no significant nuclear atypia and pleomorphism. On the immunohistochemical stain, tumor cells were positive for cytokeratin (AE1/AE3), CAM 5.2, S-100 protein, and calponin. Ultrastructurally, the cytoplasm contained thin myofilaments as well as scattered cell-to-cell attachments by desmosome. The appearances are consistent with soft tissue myoepithelioma, There was no evidence of recurrence ten months after surgery. Conclusion: An awareness of soft tissue myoepithelioma and its characteristic cytologic features and immunoreactivity with epithelial and myoepithelial markers is helpful in its correct diagnosis. Objective: An essentials part of all histological and cytological techniques is the preservation of cells and tissues. For immunocytochemistry (ICC) very important is preservation of antigens of the cells. There are various methods of fixation however each of them has advantages and disadvantages depend on results we want to achieve. In some cases available material is too small to make several smears each fixed in different way. Therefore it'd be good to have possibility to use the cell-smear second time. Aim of the Study: (1) select the best fixation method of the cellsmears for immunocytochemistry; (2) test if the second fixation in formalin of the cell-smears already processed (fixed in ethanol, stained H-E, decolorized) improve the quality of immunocytochemical staining?Material and Methods: We tested twenty cases of breast carcinoma. The cell-smears were fixed in six different ways and stained immunocytochemically (ICC) for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR) and cytokeratin AE1/AE3. Results and Conclusion: The best ICC staining we obtained in cell-smears fixed in formalin. The alcohol fixation resulted in weaker reaction but application of formalin for decolorized cellsmears improve the quality of ICC.We recommend fixation in formalin for ICC. If you have to use second time cell-smears fixed in alcohol, stained H-E and decolorized we recommend second fixation in formalin before ICC. Aims: Subcutaneous masses of the abdominal wall are uncommon. However, a variety of benign and malignant entities can be found in this region. Materials and Methods: We report a series of 46 fine-needle aspirations (FNAs) of subcutaneous masses involving the abdominal wall, witch were diagnosed over a period of nine years (2000) (2001) (2002) (2003) (2004) (2005) (2006) (2007) (2008) . There were 12 males and 34 females with an age range 3-76 years. All FNAs were done by a cytopathologist using 22-25G needles, followed by staining with Pap and MGG. Subsequently the FNAC diagnosis were correlated with the histological diagnosis (n = 39). Results: Diagnosis was possible in 45 cases. In one case the material was insufficient for diagnosis. The FNAC diagnosis included 14 soft tissue lesions (lipoma, three; desmoid fibromatosis, seven; and fibrous tumors, four), metastatic tumors (carcinoma, six and lymphoma, four), 17 endometriosis, three inflammatory process and however many singly scattered spindle cells with the same nuclear features were also present. The cytoplasm was focally vacuolated. Necrotic debris was present in the background. Immunohistochemical studies performed on the cell block material confirmed the suspected morphologic impression of epithelioid angiosarcoma. In addition, subsequent core biopsies and autopsy material reconfirmed the cytologic diagnosis. Differential diagnosis included Hü rthle cell carcinoma, anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma and metastatic carcinoma to the thyroid. Conclusion: Epithelioid angiosarcoma of the thyroid gland is a rare and aggressive neoplasm that can be accurately diagnosed by FNA. Immunocytochemical studies, clinical correlation and consideration of differential diagnostic possibilities are crucial to arrive at the correct diagnosis. Introduction: The rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common paratesticular sarcoma in children and young adults. The alveolar subtype is rarely encountered, comprising 6-10% of all paratesticular rhabdomyosarcomas. Unlike the embryonal, the alveolar subtype is associated with an unfavourable prognosis, and therefore accurate diagnosis is vital. Case Report: A 19-year-old male presented with what appeared to be a testicular tumor approximately 5cm in diameter. Upon resection, it was discovered that the tumor in fact originated in the scrotum. Cytologic imprints for a rapid intraoperative diagnosis were obtained from tiny tissue samples of the tumor. The imprints were stained with Hemacolor and Papanicolaou stains.Total tumor resection and histologic examination followed. Cytologic Features: The cytologic examination revealed mediumsized round cells with eccentric nuclei and inconspicuous nucleoli forming rosette-like structures as well as enlarged dispersed cells with compact angular cytoplasm and pleiomorphic nuclei. The cytomorphologic examination excluded a primary testicular tumor. The diagnosis was of a malignant mesenchymal tumor. Histologic Diagnosis: The histologic diagnosis was of an alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. The tumor stained positive for myoglobulin, Myo D1, SMA and desmin and negative for S-100, HCG, AFP, vimentin, CD117, PLAP, CD30, CAM 5-2, and pankeratin, confirming the initial diagnosis. Conclusion: Although rare, rhabdomyosarcoma should always be considered in the differential diagnosis of a paratesticular tumor, especially in young adults. The cytologic examination can be helpful in the diagnostic workup, particularly in excluding a primary testicular tumor and discriminating between a neoplastic and nonneoplastic lesion. Introduction: Although FNB has been well established in head and neck tumors in adults, it is not yet widely performed in children and adolescents.This study attempts to demonstrate the reliability, effectiveness and safety of this method in childhood. Materials and Methods: Our hospital is not a paediatric one, however, in a period of 6 years 76 children and adolescents, aged 6 months-16 years old, were referred to our cytology department with various head and neck tumors. In all cases FNB was performed by a cytologist, and the smears were stained with quick Giemsa (Hemacolor) and Papanicolaou stains. In 61 cases histologic examination followed, whereas in the remaining 15 the diagnosis was confirmed by patient follow-up. Results: The cytological examination revealed 61 benign and 15 malignant lesions:16 reactive lymph nodes, three cases of tuberculous lymphadenitis, seven branchial cysts, three lipomas, three neurilemmomas, three dermoid cysts, three common blue naevi, three parotid pleiomorphic adenomas, two benign fibrous histiocytomas, two benign fibrohistiocytic tumors, two benign parotid cysts, two lymphangiomas, one benign fibrous tumor, one nodular fasciitis, one hematoma, one eosinophilic granuloma, one intraparotid lipoma, one ganglial cyst, one meningioma, one juvenile xanthogranuloma, one neurinoma, one trichoepithelioma, one pilomatrixoma and one fibrolipoma, four embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas, three Hodgkin lymphomas, two dermatofibrosarcomas protuberans, two neuroblastomas, one Non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma, one lymph node infiltration from CLL, one malignant melanoma and one suspicious for liposarcoma. Correlation with available histologic examinations showed that there were no false-positive or false-negative diagnoses, whereas in eight cases there was discrepancy in neoplasm subtyping between cytology and histology. Overall concordance between cytologic and histologic diagnosis was 87%. Conclusion: In experienced hands, FNB of head and neck tumors in children and adolescents is comparable in accuracy to the FNB of head and neck tumors in adults. Therefore, it should be an essential part of the diagnostic workup in this age group as well. Objective: The purpose of this study was to assess the reproducibility of cytological diagnosis of colorectal polyps. Material and Methods: A total of 193 brushing specimens from colorectal polyps with corresponding histopathological diagnosis were reviewed. Thin Prep slides were evaluated twice by three cytopathologists with an interval of at least six months. Each reviewer was asked to categorize each slide into the following four categories: within normal limits, adenomas with low grade atypical lesions, adenomas with high grade atypical lesions and adenocarcinomas. Inadequate specimens were excluded from the study. Agreement was analysed using kappa statistics. Results: In the first round, there were difficulties in some cases concerning differential diagnosis of adenomas with high grade atypical lesions from adenocarcinomas. In the second round observer agreement was better, with kappa value between histopathological findings and cytological diagnoses 0.9. Total accuracy was 97.8%, sensitivity 98.13% and specificity 96.43%. Positive and negative predictive value was 99.37% and 90% respectively. Conclusions: The overall inter-and intraobserver agreement was good for brush cytology of colorectal polyps using Thin Prep method. Liquid based cytology appears to be highly accurate and reliable cytological method for diagnostic approach of colorectal polyps and could be added as a complementary technique to biopsy for the improvement of the diagnosis. Objective: Thyroid fine-needle aspiration (FNA) samples featuring a follicular patterned monotonous Hü rthle (oncocytic) cell population cannot reliably be diagnosed as either benign or malignant. Consequently, these lesions are eligible for surgical excision to determine their biological behavior. Most malignancy-related immunohistochemical markers proposed to reduce the number of unnecessary thyroidectomies lack sensitivity and specificity in the presence of Hü rthle cells. We recently identified cyclin D3 overexpression on histological sections of Hü rthle cell carcinomas. In the present study, we assessed the diagnostic value of cyclin D3 immunohistochemistry added to routine cytology. Material and Methods: Fifty-one FNAs suspicious for Hurtle cell neoplasia with histological follow-up (19 malignant cases) were examined. We evaluated the diagnostic value of cyclin D3 in cell block (CB) preparations and compared it to the closely related cyclin D1 protein.Results: As suggested by previous studies, the ‡25% positive cells was used as cut-off point. Cyclin D1 and D3 were highly specific (both 100%) and fairly accurate (75% versus 92%) in distinguishing benign from malignant oncocytic neoplasms, providing a strong positive predictive value (PPV; both 100%); however, their use yielded low sensibility (32% versus 79%) and low negative predictive values (NPV; 71% versus 89%). These latter parameters improved when samples positive for at least one of the cyclins were considered (sensibility: 89%; specificity: 100%; PPV: 100%; NPV: 94%; accuracy: 96%). Conversely, by adopting balanced ROC-derived positive cutoff values, cyclin D1 ( ‡6,5%) and D3 ( ‡7,5%) were highly sensible (both 100%) and accurate (90% versus 94%) in distinguishing benign from malignant oncocytic neoplasms, providing a strong NPV (both 100%); however, their yielded low specificity (84% versus 91%) and low PPV (79% versus 86%), which improved when samples positive for both cyclins were considered (sensibility: 100%; specificity: 94%; PPV: 90%; NPV: 100%; accuracy: 96%). Conclusions: Cyclin D3 increases the suspicion of malignancy in indeterminate oncocytic follicular lesions; its diagnostic performance depends on the positive cut-off point employed and is further enhanced when combined with cyclin D1. cell adenoma. In 4% (3 cases) of analyzed FNAB of parathyroid gland nodules adenoma was not properly recognized. In one case due to cystic degeneration of a nodule, in other case there were intranuclear inclusions present so it was mistaken for papillary thyroid carcinoma, and in third case it was reported as oncocytic thyroid adenoma. Conclusion: Ultrasound-guided FNAB, with data about localisation and ehosonographic structure of a nodule, assuming there is adequate material obtained, can be diagnostic for parathyroid gland adenoma in 96% of cases. Possible pitfalls are oncocytic type of parathyroid adenoma which can be mistaken for oncocytic thyroid adenoma, presence of intranuclear inclusions which can be mistaken for papillary thyroid carcinoma and cystic degeneration of a nodule because of epithelial cells absence. Mistakes can be avoided if we perform PTH level in FNAB obtained material. Introduction: Orbital tumors are relatively uncommon and the first clinical finding is unilateral exophtalmos except for some pediatric tumors, which are bilateral. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is an useful technique for evaluation of orbital tumors, however, its use is infrequent because the proximity of the eye. The close collaboration between pathologist and ophthalmologist can avoid ocular complications. Materials and Methods: In all cases the FNAC were performed using 23 and 25-gauge needle attached to a syringe and handle in the usual manner. The aspirated material was fixed as air-dried smears for Diff-Quik staining or in alcohol for the Papanicolaou method. Some material was reserved for immunohistochemical and molecular studies. Results: Most of the patients were adults. Two cases were bilateral (Rosai-Dorfman disease and embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma). The malignant tumors were less frequent than benign lesions (28 cases of malignancies and 35 cases of benign conditions) with 15 cases of metastasic tumors from breast, lung and skin. The lymphoproliferative diseases constituted 11.47% of the serie with one case of follicular hyperplasia, five non-Hodgkin lymphoma including two low-grade lymphoma and one plasmacytoma. The 35 benign lesions included cases of fibrous solitary tumor, amiloid tumor, schwannoma, lymphangioma, fibrous histyocitoma and others. The only case of the rare Erdheim-Chester disease was diagnosed as a proliferation of histiocytic cells. In this serie there were no complications in no case. Conclusion: FNAC is a rapid, easily available technique for evaluation of orbital and ocular adnexa and it avoids aggressive procedures. The close collaboration between pathologists and ophthalmologists is a necessary condition for achieving representative material. Objective: The objective of this study was to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of modified brush biopsy without computer-assisted analysis in the detection of oral premalignant and malignant lesions. Study Design: Ninety-four patients attending outpatient clinics who exhibited oral lesions suspicious of premalignancy or malignancy were enrolled. All patients underwent an oral brush biopsy using a baby toothbrush followed by a scalpel biopsy. The specimens were analyzed manually in a double-blinded fashion. Sensitivity and specificity were used for the statistical analysis of the samples. Statistical significance was determined using the normal approximation to the binomial distribution of matched results, approximated by the Student t distribution mean test (paired t test). Results: Seventy-nine patients with adequate transepithelial brush biopsy samples were included in the study group. When compared to scalpel biopsy, the statistical sensitivity of the brush biopsy was greater than 76.8% (P < .05) while the statistical specificity was greater than 93.3% (P < .05). There were 4 false negative brush biopsy cases. The 4 false negative patients turned out to be dysplasia/ malignancy on histopathology. All 4 were patients with clinical oral submucous fibrosis. Conclusion: The oral brush biopsy without computer-assisted analysis was found to be a painless, noninvasive test for evaluating oral lesions. The toothbrush brush biopsy with manual analysis had lower sensitivity and specificity than the commercially available oral brush biopsy with computer-assisted analysis. The results demonstrate that by using a toothbrush to obtain an oral brush biopsy sample, oral lesions can be easily evaluated in a resource challenged settings to rule out dysplasia and carcinoma. Objectives: Male factors are responsible for about half of all infertility cases. Until recently, testicular biopsy was the standard method to ascertain the aetiology of azoospermia. Fine needle aspiration cytology has gained increasing popularity as a simple and minimally invasive procedure that can help in assessing testicular function accurately. This study was aimed at addressing the question whether testicular fine needle aspiration (FNA) may be used as a first-line diagnostic modality in azoospermia and to assess its usefulness in the diagnostic protocol.

The FNA was performed in 78 consecutive azoospermic patients. To obviate sampling errors both testes were aspirated, except when contraindicated. Routine haematoxylin and eosin as well as Romanowsky staining was performed on the smears. Results: The smears were categorized on cytological examination into normal spermatogenesis in 35 (50%) patients, Sertoli cells only syndrome in 22 (31.4%) and maturation arrest at the spermatocyte/spermatid level was seen in 13 (18.4%) patients. There were eight (10.2%) cases with scant smears where cytological diagnosis could not be made. A good correlation between cytological smears and histological sections was found in 54 of 58 testes (93.1%) in which histopathological confirmation was available. Conclusions: Testicular FNA may be utilized as a first-line investigative modality in patients with azoospermia, provided the procedure is performed and interpreted by experts. Objectives: The application of image analysis system in order to measure morphological parameters on immunochemistry stains is an important procedure in the interpretation of breast cancer biopsies. The aim of this study is to investigate the influence of JPG Compression on these parameters. Materials and Methods: Seventy-five cases of breast FNA's have been analyzed by a non-medical person (Medical Physicist) using a custom image analysis system (Image Pro Plus) connected to a color digital camera. After the digitization of the slides and the nuclei segmentation, in the above cases 24 morphometrical parameters (area, optical density, perimeter e.t.c) as well as label index, quick score and heterogeneity concentration have been measured.The initial non compressed images were saved using the common compression algorithm JPEG, at several compression levels. The same parameters were measured for the original and the compressed images and the values have been added in a database in order to perform statistical analysis. Results: Measurements do not differ for various levels of compression. However, according to the compression level measured results were distinct, but a very good correlation can be observed among them (r > 0.85 and P < 0.01). Conclusions: The fact that common image compression does not affect significantly the morphological parameters indicates that a cytopathology department could easily use telemedicine applications in daily clinical practice since compressed images could be sent faster without loosing diagnostic information.right upper lung with irregular margins and a cystic lesion in the right thoracic wall that was expanded up to the pleura. Several smears were taken from the lesion. Both conventional and liquid based cytology methods were stained with Papanicolaou, May Gr} unwald Giemsa stain and microbiology conventional stains. Results: Smears screening revealed the presence of a neutrophilic clustering with a number of very small deep dark corpuscules that special laboratory studies revealed the presence of Sporothrix Schenckii. Conclusions: We wish to emphasize the contribution of FNA cytology as the first approach in the evaluation of sporotrichosis in parallel with the exclusion of malignancy and tuberculosis. Objective: Evaluation of cytologic features of distant/unusual presentations of lung carcinoma in two challenging cases. Materials and Methods: Cytologic material from two cases of lung cancers, one previously unknown, was examined in our institution. Patient 1 presented in an outpatient clinic with a 1.5 cm soft tissue nodule in the left peri-umbilical area. The nodule was sampled by fine needle aspiration, using a 23 gauge needle, 5/8 inch in length, attached to a 10 cc syringe, mounted on a Cameco Ò syringe holder. Air dried Diff-Quik Ó and alcohol-fixed Papanicolaou stained slides were examined. Patient 2 was a 48 year old woman with a history of widely disseminated lung carcinoma, who presented to her gynaecologist with inter-menstrual spotting. A cervico-vaginal sample processed for a thin-prep Ò slide and an endometrial biopsy were simultaneously obtained and routinely processed. Immunohistochemistry was employed to process case 2. Results: FNA evaluation of peri-umbilical nodule in patient 1 showed epithelial cells in variably sized three dimensional clusters and single cells with dense cytoplasm, intercellular bridges and pleomorphic and hyperchromatic nuclei. Some of these malignant cells were bizarre and overtly keratinized, allowing an unequivocal diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma with lung likely being the primary site. Subsequent chest x-ray confirmed a left lung nodule, which at CT guided biopsy was confirmed as primary squamous cell carcinoma. Cervicovaginal cytology in the second patient showed three-dimensional small clusters of glandular cells. Cells were characterized by cytoplasmic vacuoles displacing the nuclei that were pleomorphic and hyperchromatic. Tumor diathesis or a bloody background was not evident. A diagnosis of adenocarcinoma, favour extrauterine, was rendered, pending further immunohistochemical evaluation. A concurrent endometrial biopsy reproduced the tumor cell features that were seen at cytology. Immunohistochemical evaluation with thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) (positive) and thyroglobulin (negative) confirmed this case to be lung adenocarcinoma metastatic to endometrium. Conclusion: Metastatic lung carcinoma can present in unusual locations including subcutaneous tissue and endometrium. When accessible, metastatic overt lesions may easily and safely be sampled with a fine needle to produce meaningful samples that can aid in triaging the case further and can cut down the treatment cost significantly. Very rarely, metastatic tumor may also be seen in cervicovaginal samples when endometrium is involved. In such a setting, awareness of patient history and clinical findings and the presence of tumor cells in the cervico-vaginal sample can alert for the possibility of a metastatic lesion. Tumor diathesis or old blood, features typical of an endometrial primary adenocarcinoma, are typically absent and immunohistochemical evaluation for TTF-1 can help in identifying lung likely to be the primary source. Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma from lung would look no different from primary cervical squamous cell carcinoma at cytology, but the former is much less likely to be positive for P16, a surrogate marker for high risk HPV, a ubiquitous etiologic causative agent for cervical squamous cell carcinoma. Introduction: Endobronchial ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (EBUS-FNA) is an accurate and useful procedure for the diagnosis of thoracic lesions and mediastinal lymph node staging for lung cancer. Objective: To evaluate the non-neoplastic pathology diagnosed by means of EBUS-FNA.
